required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Albuterol HFA MDI in Pediatric Participants With Asthma
clinical_study.official_title: Phase 3 Study to Evaluate the Chronic-dose Safety and Efficacy of Albuterol-HFA-MDI Relative to Placebo in Pediatric Asthmatics

lead_sponsor.agency: Teva Branded Pharmaceutical Products, R&D Inc.

brief_summary.textblock: The primary objective of this study is to evaluate the chronic-dose and efficacy of Albuterol-HFA-MDI relative to placebo in pediatric asthmatics.

study_design_info.masking: Quadruple (Participant, Care Provider, Investigator, Outcomes Assessor)

primary_outcome.measure: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Observed up to Two Hours Post Dose (FEV1max%0-2) on Day 22
primary_outcome.time_frame: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5, 45±5, 60±10, 120 ±10 post dosing on Day 22 or last observation
primary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in FEV1 observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing using Day 22 baseline. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.

primary_outcome.measure: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Observed up to Two Hours Post Dose (PEFmax%0-2) on Day 22
primary_outcome.time_frame: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing, and at 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing on Day 22 or last observation
primary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in the PEF observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing using Day 22 baseline. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) up to Two Hours Post-Dose (FEV1max%0-2, %) on Study Days 1 and 22 Using Observed Cases
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5, 45±5, 60±10, 120 ±10 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in FEV1 observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing using test day baseline. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) up to Two Hours Post-Dose (PEFmax%0-2) on Study Days 1 and 22 Using Observed Cases
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing, and 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in the PEF observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing on study days 1 and 22. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline Adjusted Area-under-the-Effect Curve for Percent of Predicted Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Over 6 Hours Post-dose on Day 22 Using Both Day 1 and Day 22 Baselines
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Day 1 or Day 22: 35±5 and 10±2 minutes prior to dosing), Day 22 (5±2, 15±5, 30±5, 45±5, 60±10, 120±10, 240±10, and 360±10 minutes post-dosing or last observation)
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Values are then expressed as the percentage of FE1 values predicted for a 'normal' population. Predicted FEV1 values were computed and adjusted for age, height and gender according to Eigen et al. for subjects 4-5 years of age and to Quanjer et al. for subjects aged 6-11 years using American Thoracic Society (ATS) criteria. The area under-the-effect curves for percent-predicted FEV1 were calculated according to the trapezoidal rule and were based on actual (not scheduled) measurement times.

secondary_outcome.measure: Baseline-Adjusted Area-under-the Effect Curve for Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Over 6 Hours Post-dose on Day 22 Using Both Day 1 and Day 22 Baselines
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Baseline (Day 1 or Day 22: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing Day 22: 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing or last observation
secondary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. The area under-the-effect curves for PEF were calculated according to the trapezoidal rule and were based on actual (not scheduled) measurement times.

secondary_outcome.measure: Maximum Percent-Predicted FEV1 (Max PPFEV1, %) Observed up to Two Hours Following Completion of Dosing on Study Days 1 and 22 (Observed Case)
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Values are then expressed as the percentage of FE1 values predicted for a 'normal' population. Predicted FEV1 values were computed and adjusted for age, height and gender according to Eigen et al. for subjects 4-5 years of age and to Quanjer et al. for subjects aged 6-11 years using American Thoracic Society (ATS) criteria.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time To Maximum Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5, 45±5, 60±10, 120 ±10 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Time to maximum FEV1 is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline FEV1 to increase to the highest FEV1 post dose during the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time To Maximum Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing, and 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. Time to maximum PEF is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline PEF to increase to the highest PEF post-dose for the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant Responses: Percentage of Participants With a >=15% Increase in Baseline FEV1 Within 30 Minutes Post-Dose on Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. This outcome counts participants who responded to therapy by obtaining a >+15% increase in FEV1 within 30 minutes of dose. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant Responses: Percentage of Participants With a >=12% Increase in Baseline FEV1 Within 30 Minutes Post-Dose on Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. This outcome counts participants who responded to therapy by obtaining a >+12% increase in FEV1 within 30 minutes of dose. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant Responses: Percentage of Participants With a >=15% Increase in Baseline PEF Within 30 Minutes Post-Dose on Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. This outcome counts participants who responded to therapy by obtaining a >+15% increase in PEF within 30 minutes of dose. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participant Responses: Percentage of Participants With a >=12% Increase in Baseline PEF Within 30 Minutes Post-Dose on Days 1 and 22
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5 post dosing
secondary_outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. This outcome counts participants who responded to therapy by obtaining a >+12% increase in PEF within 30 minutes of dose. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values.

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Average Highest (Worst) Daily Asthma Symptom Scores for Weeks 1, 2 and 3
secondary_outcome.description: Highest daily asthma symptom scores by study week. For this assessment, patients self-evaluate and record on the diary card the following asthma symptoms experienced during the day (i.e. last 12-14 hours): wheeze, shortness of breath, cough, tightness of chest. The worst of these symptoms were scored daily on a four-point scale: 0 = No symptoms occurred 1 = Symptom occurred but did not interfere with daily activity 2 = Symptom occurred but was sometimes annoying or interfered with daily activity 3 = Symptom present even at rest and was annoying or interfered with daily activity

secondary_outcome.measure: The Number of Asthma-Related Nocturnal Awakenings Per Week Requiring the Use of Rescue Medication
secondary_outcome.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night.

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Average Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Obtained Pre-Dose Each Morning
secondary_outcome.description: Participants measured their PEF as trained by taking as deep a breath as possible, placing their mouth firmly around the mouthpiece of the flow meter to form a tight seal, and exhaling as hard and as fast as possible. Subjects repeated the process twice at intervals of approximately 30 seconds, and then recorded the highest of the three PEF values on the diary card.

secondary_outcome.measure: Weekly Average Number of Puffs of Rescue Medication Taken Each Day for Study Weeks 1, 2 and 3
secondary_outcome.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night and the number of puffs of rescue albuterol used during the night after going to bed. At the end of each day, the number of puffs of albuterol rescue medication used during the day were recorded.

arm_group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days. HFA-MDI refers to a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) utilizing a hydrofluoroalkane (HFA) propellant.
A placebo of a metered-dose inhaler (MDI) utilizing a hydrofluoroalkane (HFA) propellant. (Hereafter noted as "Placebo-HFA-MDI.")

intervention.description: Albuterol HFA MDI 180 mcg four times a day (q.i.d) for a total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg for 21 days.
Placebo HFA MDI four times a day (q.i.d) for 21 days.

Proventil® HFA (albuterol sulfate) Inhalation Aerosol (Key Pharmaceuticals) was used as rescue medication in this study. The rescue medication was over-labeled with instructions for emergency use in which subjects were instructed to self-administer up to two puffs every 20 minutes to a maximum of six puffs for any given episode while attempting to seek medical assistance.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Male and female child aged 4-11 years, inclusive Asthma of a minimum of six months duration that has been stable for at least four weeks prior to screening.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Hospitalization for acute asthma exacerbation greater than two years in 12 months prior to screening and/or received ER treatment or hospitalization for asthma exacerbation.

facility.name: Center for Clinical Trials of Sacramento
Clinical Research Institute of Southern Oregan, PC

participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: 208 individual subjects were screened; ten subjects failed the initial screening but were later re-screened and successfully enrolled.

outcome.title: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Observed up to Two Hours Post Dose (FEV1max%0-2) on Day 22
outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in FEV1 observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing using Day 22 baseline. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.

measure.title: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Observed up to Two Hours Post Dose (FEV1max%0-2) on Day 22

analysis.groups_desc: Efficacy was declared if the test for either primary efficacy endpoint was significant at the 0.025 level.
analysis.p_value_desc: In order to control the overall alpha level at the 0.05 value, each of the primary endpoints were tested separately at the 0.025 level of significance.
analysis.method_desc: Baseline as covariate and fixed effects of treatment and pooled investigator site.

Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in the PEF observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing using Day 22 baseline. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.

measure.title: Maximum Percent Change From Baseline in Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) up to Two Hours Post-Dose (FEV1max%0-2, %) on Study Days 1 and 22 Using Observed Cases
measure.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. analysis.groups_desc: Day 1 A repeated measures mixed model, with terms for treatment, pooled center, study day, treatment by study day interaction, and baseline as a covariate, and subject as a random term, was used to make comparisons between placebo and active with respect to FEV1max%0-2 at Days 1 and 22, with observed case data.

Day 22 A repeated measures mixed model, with terms for treatment, pooled center, study day, treatment by study day interaction, and baseline as a covariate, and subject as a random term, was used to make comparisons between placebo and active with respect to FEV1max%0-2 at Days 1 and 22, with observed case data.

A standardized spirometer was used with the subject in the sitting or standing position (orientation had to be consistent for each subject during study visits) and wearing a nose clip. Whenever possible, evaluations were performed by the same respiratory therapist on the same calibrated spirometer at approximately the same time (±2 hrs). The maximum percent change from baseline in the PEF observed up to 2 hours following completion of dosing on study days 1 and 22. The baseline PEF was defined as the average of the test-day pre-dose baseline PEF values. The reason for the two primary endpoints was that FEV1 is difficult to obtain in children below 7 years of age.
outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing, and 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing

group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.title: Baseline-Adjusted Area-under-the Effect Curve for Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Over 6 Hours Post-dose on Day 22 Using Both Day 1 and Day 22 Baselines
measure.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. The area under-the-effect curves for PEF were calculated according to the trapezoidal rule and were based on actual (not scheduled) measurement times.
measure.population: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) population with Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF)

analysis.method_desc: terms for treatment and center, baseline as a covariate
terms for treatment and center, baseline as a covariate

outcome.title: Maximum Percent-Predicted FEV1 (Max PPFEV1, %) Observed up to Two Hours Following Completion of Dosing on Study Days 1 and 22 (Observed Case)
outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Values are then expressed as the percentage of FE1 values predicted for a 'normal' population. Predicted FEV1 values were computed and adjusted for age, height and gender according to Eigen et al. for subjects 4-5 years of age and to Quanjer et al. for subjects aged 6-11 years using American Thoracic Society (ATS) criteria.

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo-HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.title: Maximum Percent-Predicted FEV1 (Max PPFEV1, %) Observed up to Two Hours Following Completion of Dosing on Study Days 1 and 22 (Observed Case)
measure.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Values are then expressed as the percentage of FE1 values predicted for a 'normal' population. Predicted FEV1 values were computed and adjusted for age, height and gender according to Eigen et al. for subjects 4-5 years of age and to Quanjer et al. for subjects aged 6-11 years using American Thoracic Society (ATS) criteria.

analysis.method_desc: terms for treatment, center, time, time x treatment, subject as a random
terms for treatment, center, time, time x treatment, subject as a random

outcome.title: Time To Maximum Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Time to maximum FEV1 is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline FEV1 to increase to the highest FEV1 post dose during the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.
outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5, 45±5, 60±10, 120 ±10 post dosing
outcome.population: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) population; Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) used for Day 22

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

measure.title: Time To Maximum Forced Expiratory Volume in One Second (FEV1) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
measure.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. Time to maximum FEV1 is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline FEV1 to increase to the highest FEV1 post dose during the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.
measure.population: Intent-To-Treat (ITT) population; Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) used for Day 22

outcome.title: Time To Maximum Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
outcome.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. Time to maximum PEF is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline PEF to increase to the highest PEF post-dose for the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.
outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 30±5 and 5±2 minutes prior to dosing, and 7.5±2, 20±5, 35±5, 50±5, 65±10, 125±10 post dosing
outcome.population: ITT population; Last Observation Carried Forward (LOCF) used for Day 22

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

measure.title: Time To Maximum Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Over Six Hours Post-Dose On Days 1 and 22
measure.description: The PEF test is conducted by having a person blow as hard as they can into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the rate of air blown. Time to maximum PEF is defined as the number of minutes required for the baseline PEF to increase to the highest PEF post-dose for the 6 hour observation period. Median time and confidence intervals obtained via separate Kaplan-Meier estimates for each study day.

outcome.title: Participant Responses: Percentage of Participants With a >=15% Increase in Baseline FEV1 Within 30 Minutes Post-Dose on Days 1 and 22
outcome.description: The FEV1 test is conducted by having a person empty their lungs of air into a mouthpiece attached to a sensor that measures the amount of air blown measured in liters. This outcome counts participants who responded to therapy by obtaining a >+15% increase in FEV1 within 30 minutes of dose. The baseline FEV1 was defined as the average of the two test-day pre-dose baseline FEV1 values.
outcome.time_frame: Days 1 and 22: 35±5 and 10±2 min prior to dosing, and at 5±2, 15±5, 30±5 post dosing

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

outcome.title: Weekly Average Highest (Worst) Daily Asthma Symptom Scores for Weeks 1, 2 and 3
outcome.description: Highest daily asthma symptom scores by study week. For this assessment, patients self-evaluate and record on the diary card the following asthma symptoms experienced during the day (i.e. last 12-14 hours): wheeze, shortness of breath, cough, tightness of chest. The worst of these symptoms were scored daily on a four-point scale: 0 = No symptoms occurred 1 = Symptom occurred but did not interfere with daily activity 2 = Symptom occurred but was sometimes annoying or interfered with daily activity 3 = Symptom present even at rest and was annoying or interfered with daily activity

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.description: Highest daily asthma symptom scores by study week. The worst of these symptoms were scored daily on a four-point scale: 0 = No symptoms occurred 1 = Symptom occurred but did not interfere with daily activity 2 = Symptom occurred but was sometimes annoying or interfered with daily activity 3 = Symptom present even at rest and was annoying or interfered with daily activity

outcome.title: The Number of Asthma-Related Nocturnal Awakenings Per Week Requiring the Use of Rescue Medication
outcome.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night.

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.title: The Number of Asthma-Related Nocturnal Awakenings Per Week Requiring the Use of Rescue Medication
measure.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night.

outcome.title: Weekly Average Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Obtained Pre-Dose Each Morning
outcome.description: Participants measured their PEF as trained by taking as deep a breath as possible, placing their mouth firmly around the mouthpiece of the flow meter to form a tight seal, and exhaling as hard and as fast as possible. Subjects repeated the process twice at intervals of approximately 30 seconds, and then recorded the highest of the three PEF values on the diary card.

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.title: Weekly Average Peak Expiratory Flow (PEF) Obtained Pre-Dose Each Morning
measure.description: Participants measured their PEF as trained by taking as deep a breath as possible, placing their mouth firmly around the mouthpiece of the flow meter to form a tight seal, and exhaling as hard and as fast as possible. Subjects repeated the process twice at intervals of approximately 30 seconds, and then recorded the highest of the three PEF values on the diary card.

terms for treatment, center, week, week by treatment, baseline as a covariate, subject as random.

outcome.title: Weekly Average Number of Puffs of Rescue Medication Taken Each Day for Study Weeks 1, 2 and 3
outcome.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night and the number of puffs of rescue albuterol used during the night after going to bed. At the end of each day, the number of puffs of albuterol rescue medication used during the day were recorded.

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day (total daily albuterol dose of 720 mcg) for 21 days.

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

measure.title: Weekly Average Number of Puffs of Rescue Medication Taken Each Day for Study Weeks 1, 2 and 3
measure.description: Participants recorded every morning on awakening the number of asthma-related nocturnal awakenings requiring use of rescue medication that occurred during the previous night and the number of puffs of rescue albuterol used during the night after going to bed. At the end of each day, the number of puffs of albuterol rescue medication used during the day were recorded.

analysis.groups_desc: Week 1 P-value, mean and confidence interval calculated from a 0 inflated mixed poisson regression model with fixed effect terms for treatment, week, treatment by week interaction, baseline as a covariate and a random term for subject. The null hypothesis is that the ratio equals 1. Estimated means are conditional upon the random effect, assume a random effect of 0 and a covariate value at the average.

Week 2 P-value, mean and confidence interval calculated from a 0 inflated mixed poisson regression model with fixed effect terms for treatment, week, treatment by week interaction, baseline as a covariate and a random term for subject. The null hypothesis is that the ratio equals 1. Estimated means are conditional upon the random effect, assume a random effect of 0 and a covariate value at the average.

Week 3 P-value, mean and confidence interval calculated from a 0 inflated mixed poisson regression model with fixed effect terms for treatment, week, treatment by week interaction, baseline as a covariate and a random term for subject. The null hypothesis is that the ratio equals 1. Estimated means are conditional upon the random effect, assume a random effect of 0 and a covariate value at the average.

group.title: Albuterol
group.description: Albuterol-HFA-MDI 180 mcg, four times a day

group.title: Placebo
group.description: Placebo HFA-MDI four times a day for 21 days.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: Sponsor has the right 60 days before submission for publication to review/provide comments. If review shows that potentially patentable subject matter would be disclosed, publication or public disclosure may be delayed for up to 90 additional days to file the necessary patent applications. In multicenter trials, each PI will postpone single center publications until after disclosure of multicenter data, but not longer than 12 months from study completion/termination at all participating sites.
